headline: Mojo-Marinated Grilled Chicken Recipe
description: On a quest to duplicate my one of my favorite chickens of all time, I finally hit the nail on the headâ€”mojo sauce! A base of sour orange mixed with oil, garlic, oregano, and cumin serves as a marinade and baste for this bird, and what comes off the rotisserie in the end is a sight for sore eyes and a party for the tastebuds.
name: Mojo-Marinated Grilled Chicken Recipe
recipeIngredient: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste

recipeInstructions.text: To make the mojo sauce, whisk together the olive oil, orange juice, lime juice, lemon juice, garlic, oregano, cumin, salt, and pepper in a medium bowl. Set aside.

Wash the chicken inside and out and remove any excess fat. Place in a large Ziploc bag and pour in about 2/3 of the mojo sauce, reserving the rest. Seal the bag and toss to evenly distribute the marinade, then open and reseal the bag, removing as much air as possible. Let marinate in the refrigerator for 2 to 6 hours.

Remove the chicken from the refrigerator and let come to room temperature while you prepare the grill. Light a chimney 3/4 full of charcoal. When the charcoal is fully lit and covered in gray ash, pour the coals out and arrange them on either side of the charcoal grate, keeping the middle empty. Place chicken on the rotisserie and cook at 300 degrees until an instant read thermometer registers 165 degrees in the thickest part of the breast, about 1 1/2 hours. Baste the chicken every 20-30 minutes with the reserved mojo sauce while cooking. Remove the chicken from the rotisserie and let rest for 15 minutes, carve and serve.

review.reviewBody: The recipe should specify a salt measurement. Salting the marinade to taste will leave you with very undersalted chicken. I regret not looking up a brine recipe to figure out how much to use for the weight of chicken we had.

I grew up with my Cuban parents in Miami. Mojo is a staple there - every (savory) food gets some - we put it in the beans (black/red/garbanzo/etc.), on every meat we cook (beef, chicken, lamb, even fish, but ESPECIALLY PORK!), on the Thanksgiving turkey, on the plantains, on fries, anything! It's used as a marinade, as a sauce on the side, as a baste... it's very versatile. I might suggest that you add some grapefruit juice along with the orange/lemon/lime juice to turn up the tartness and add a different layer of flavor.

As one who grills year round in the Midwest (cold winters) I would say that the marinade could be used on bonless chicken breasts. I would not marinade it much more than an hour or so due to all of the citrus. That said, I would also use a piece of chicken with skin on; you can remove the bone if you don't want it. This recipe, as I read it, is about having a nice, crisp skin.

Looks like it has great flavor. I will try it, even though I don't have a rotisserie for my charcoal grill. (When a recipe calls for charcoal, by all means use it!)
Has anyone tried this marinade on boneless chicken breasts (for grilling)?
Do I need to put some of the marinade aside for the basting , or can I take the marinade and bring to a boil, and then use it as a basting glaze ?......
